sectiondef.header: PIN 01, GPIO10, uses Timer0B for Capture.
PIN 02, GPIO11, uses Timer1A for Capture.
PIN 03, GPIO12, uses Timer1B for Capture.
PIN 04, GPIO13, uses Timer2A for Capture.
PIN 05, GPIO14, uses Timer2B for Capture.
PIN 06, GPIO15, uses Timer3A for Capture.
PIN 07, GPIO16, uses Timer3B for Capture.
PIN 15, GPIO22, uses Timer2A for Capture.
PIN 17, GPIO24 (TDO), uses Timer3A for Capture.
PIN 50, GPIO0, uses Timer0A for Capture.
PIN 53, GPIO30, uses Timer2B for Capture.
PIN 55, GPIO1, uses Timer0B for Capture.
PIN 57, GPIO2, uses Timer1A for Capture.
PIN 60, GPIO5, uses Timer2B for Capture.
PIN 61, GPIO6, uses Timer3A for Capture.
PIN 63, GPIO8, uses Timer3A for Capture.
PIN 64, GPIO9, uses Timer0A for Capture.

briefdescription.para: Capture driver interface for CC32XX devices.

detaileddescription.para: This driver uses a general purpose timer hardware peripheral to implement the capture functionality. The capture driver only uses half of a timer peripheral (16-bit timer). This is not a software limitation but due to the general purpose timer hardware implementation. For CC32XX devices, the system clock is 80 MHz. A 16-bit timer peripheral has 24-bits of resolution when the prescaler register is used as an 8-bit linear extension.

Each general purpose timer block contains two timers, Timer A and Timer B, that can be configured to operate independently. This behavior is managed through a set of resource allocation APIs. For example, the TimerCC32XX_allocateTimerResource API will allocate a timer for exclusive use. Any attempt to re-allocate this resource by the TimerCC32XX, PWMCC32XX, or CaptureCC32xx drivers will result in a false value being returned from the allocation API. To free a timer resource, the TimerCC32XX_freeTimerResource is used. The application is not responsible for calling these allocation APIs directly.

This device implementation only works with the following modes for Capture_Mode :
Capture_RISING_EDGE
Capture_FALLING_EDGE
Capture_ANY_EDGE All other modes will fail.
